Several years ago I worked for a grocery store in Philadelphia. I remember one day an Egyptian couple who had just immigrated to the United States came in and saw chocolate milk for the first time. And of course they had all kinds of questions about it: like how it was made and if it was good. Then they bought a gallon of it, and they were so excited.

Now for me chocolate milk sort of old hat, but for them, it was an amazing new thing they had never seen before. They were probably in their late 20s, but for a few moments they as giddy as little kids about this. And it might seem silly, but this was one of those moments when I realized how sometimes, the things we take for granted, other people find new and fascinating. While it was just an encounter with strangers in a grocery store, it stands out in my memory as a moment when I saw the world around me through someone else's eyes. While rockets are old hat to you, that little boy you pointed out gave a new perspective.

I'm in the Philippines. The rainy season is coming to an end, and I've got two survivors from last year, two new completed and four more "in the white". When the dry season arrives, I'll be going around to the high schools with my rockets. I'll spend a little time with the science teacher, leave him with some printed information, and have a little demonstration in the sports field. The kids love seeing the rockets fly and some are inspired to learn more.

The happiest time of my life was running a farm-based educational project - real kids, real world and could take a session wherever it needed to go to give them 'real' education - maths, geography, science, history was all there for real and not in a book.
The pay was awful, but the rewards were huge...
